abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project in Lesotho
            was achieved. The project succeeded in providing eight new
            and ten expanded Community Junior Secondary School (CJSS)
            with the necessary facilities. The overall physical
            objectives and a substantial part of the qualitative
            objectives of the project have been achieved, although the
            full impact of the project awaits later evaluation. The lack
            of a full-time project architect and quantity surveyor
            handicapped implementation, which in this case was also
            delayed by unresolved policy matters regarding the Brigades.
            The fact that the status of the Brigade Centers emerged as
            an issue soon after the start of implementation suggested
            that appraisal of this component was inadequate. The
            Bank's inability to accommodate the Government's
            request to utilize surplus funds to increase the number of
            schools to be constructed or expanded showed that the
            project design did not allow for such variation during
            implementation. The main lesson would no doubt be that a
            strong and efficient unit for the implementation of
            externally financed project is a necessity. Unfortunately,
            it does not follow from such a statement how this can be
            achieved. It might be suggested that the Government and the
            Bank discuss between them possible ways to better integrate
            Boipelago Education Project Unit (BEPU) into the overall
            structure of the Ministry of Education.
